The Cotopaxi School District is closely monitoring information related to the novel coronavirus 2019, which is commonly referred to as COVID-19. At the present time, there are cases of COVID-19 in Colorado and within the United States. The District is proactively working to be prepared for cases of COVID-19 in Colorado and, more specifically, Fremont County. Cotopaxi Schools Administration & School Nurse are working closely with Fremont County Public Health & the Center for Disease Control (CDC) monitoring the situation; adjustments to our crisis plan will be made as needed.

br.font: As everyone is aware, growing concern and stricter requirements are issued daily regarding COVID-19. Let me assure you as a district we take this very seriously and are in full compliance with all guidelines. Although we have NO suspected or positive cases of COVID-19 within our county we want to take a proactive stance for the safety and well being of our students, staff and community. Therefore, we will extend our spring break window by closing schools beginning March 16th. We plan on resuming school on March 30th. We will continue to monitor all information and guidelines closely with Fremont and Chaffee County Health along with our local and state agencies to be able to provide you with any further developments. Please refer to our website for information and links to valuable resources on COVID-19. Please note that all school or community events scheduled for March 13th-March 29th at the school are cancelled.
We sincerely apologize for any inconvenience this may cause and appreciate your understanding as we carefully navigate through this rapidly evolving situation.

font.span:
Located at the western end of Fremont County, School District RE-3 includes five small communities, all within 12 miles of the school, located in Cotopaxi. Four of the five communities are located along the Arkansas River at the base of the Sangre de Cristo Mountain Range, approximately halfway between Salida and Canon City on U.S. Hwy 50. The school ties these five separate communities together.
There is no main industry in the area, but ranching, rafting, recreation, tourism, and the Colorado Department of Corrections employ many people. The recreational possibilities in the area are outstanding and include: Fishing, hunting, backpacking, camping, four wheeling, river rafting, and skiing, are all available within an hour’s drive.
The school employs 20 teachers, two administrators, one counselor and 23 support personnel. The district is a member of South-Central Board of Cooperative Educational Services (BOCES).
The district has approximately 108 students in Cotopaxi Early Learning Center and Elementary School, and 118 students in Cotopaxi Junior-Senior High School.
The district has been on a four-day week schedule since 1980. School begins at 7:56 A.M. and continues until 4:04 P.M., Monday through Thursday. Fridays are utilized for teacher staff development, parent-teacher conferences, and extra curricular activities.
